huntYears.SEASON_DATE_TEXT: Archery Only: Aug 19 - Aug 31, 2023 ALW: Sept 1, 2023 - Jan 15, 2024

huntMaster.SPECIAL_INSTRUCTIONS:
Holders of this permit may hunt any open limited entry unit.
This permit may not hunt Antelope Island or CWMUs
huntMaster.SPECIAL_PROVISIONS: This permit is available as the Statewide Sportsman's Permit by applying for the permit in the late fall or by obtaining the Statewide Conservation Permit available to purchase through the approved conservation organization. See guidebook or contact a regional office for details.
huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP:
The majority of land is managed by the BLM. There is a significant amount of SITLA land. There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA). These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas. There is private land and some of it is accessible through the DWR’s Walk-in-Access Program
http://wildlife.utah.gov/walkinaccess/
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, and Willow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html) BLM: 14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days. DWR WMA’S: UDWR WMAs are limited to 14 days at one location. On the Willow Creek WMA, camping is not allowed. In the parcels that can be accessed by county roads there is no camping allowed. Camping is only allowed in the parcels where the roads are closed, like Meadow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The Seep Ridge road is the best way to access where the bison are located.  You can stay on this road until you come to the Book Cliffs Divide.  Once on the Divide road I would travel west to Winter Ridge and Rock Springs Mesa.  You can also access the Divide from I-70 using the Hay Canyon Road.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office and SITLA. The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.
This unit includes the Book Cliffs Little Creek WMA (Roadless Area). There is no vehicle access in this area and you are limited to horse or foot travel.

Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads. There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape. There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them. Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access. There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads. The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.
There are two roads that allow you to drive across the majority of the Book Cliffs. The Kings Well Road starts at the Seep Ridge Road on the west side, and it can take you all the way to the Dragon Road on the east side. The Indian Ridge Road starts at the Seep Ridge Road and goes through the bottom of Sweetwater, the top of McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek and to Big Park. It is a great road to locate deer during this time of year.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands. There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit. Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads. All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.
There are some private ranches that post their property. There are also privately owned lands that allow access through the DWR Walk-in-Access Program.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at Exit 164 on I-70 near the town of Green River; east on I-70 to the Utah-Colorado state line; north on this state line to the White River; west along this river to the Green River; south along this river to Swasey's Boat Ramp and the Hastings Road; south on this road to SR-19; south and east on SR-19 to Exit 164 on 1-70 near the town of Green River. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THE BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Seep Ridge, Westwater. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700 or the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Ownership is approximately 95% Public Land - BLM, and State lands.  There are small isolated tracts of private lands representing less than 5% of the unit.  These private lands include the mouths of most the major canyons coming out of the Book Cliffs and the irrigated fields near the town of Green River.  These private lands will be more of an impact for deer hunters than pronghorn or bighorn sheep hunters.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Nash Wash WMA.  It is accessed from Exit 204 off of Interstate 70.  It will be a very good area for mule deer but marginal for pronghorn and bighorn sheep.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: The only developed campground on the unit is at Swasey's Beach along the Green River and is administered by the BLM. It is a good campground that is very near good sheep hunting opportunities.   Dispersed camping opportunities on SITLA and BLM lands across the desert are abundant.  Firewood and water are relatively scarce.  Plan on bringing your own water.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: The yellow 1:100,000 scale BLM maps named Westwater, Huntington, and Moab.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
ATV and Vehicle Access: allowed on approved roads and trails

Bighorn Sheep: Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and are covered on its Travel Management Plan. There are only a few roads that go on or near bighorn sheep habitat on the unit. The Hastings Road just east of the Green River in the town of Green River will take you along the east side of the Green River for about 15 miles until the road dead-ends near Rattlesnake Canyon. This road will provide the closest access to where most of the sheep live. This road is graded by the county and is generally in good shape. There are some tight spots along the river that you should be wary of if there is snowy or icy conditions. The Tushar Canyon road will go northeast off of the Hastings Road about 9 miles north of the town of Green River. It will access the right and left fork of Tushar Canyon and loop around along the bench to the east and provide access to Coal, Horse, and Floy Canyons. The Coal Canyon Road is the first right hand turn off of the Hastings Road while still in the town of Green River. It will go through a bunch of alfalfa fields and then up on the cliffs. the Horse Canyon and Floy Canyon roads can be access by following the frontage road along I-70 to the east. Despite all of these directions, most of your time will be spent on foot.

Deer: The main areas with the highest concentrations of deer include Nash Wash (Exit 204 off of Interstate 70), Cottonwood Canyon (Exit 214), Hay Canyon (Exit 221), and Bitter Creek (Exit 227)

Pronghorn: Use any exit off of Interstate 70 or drive the frontage road along the Interstate. Major access points include Green River (Exit 164), Floy Wash (Exit 175), Crescent Junction, Thompson, Yellowcat, Nash Wash (Exit 204), Cottonwood (Exit 214), Sulphur Canyon (Exit 221), and Bitter Creek (Exit 227)
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
Bighorn Sheep: The northern boundary of this unit adjoins Ute Tribal lands along Coal Creek. This is good bighorn sheep habitat and bighorns have been seen on both sides of the boundary near the mouth of Coal Creek. Take great care not to hunt or trespass on these tribal lands. The upper Tribal Boundary at upper elevations near Sego Canyon generally doesn't have bighorn sheep during November. There are small isolated pieces of private property in the mouths of Coal, Horse, Floy, and Thompson Canyons. County roads go through these properties so it is best to simply travel through them and park on public lands if you do not have written permission to hunt on these private lands. Bighorn sheep generally do not spend a great deal of time on these private lands.

Pronghorn: There is a large block of private land on the alfalfa fields near the town of Green River. Antelope use this area. Please secure written permission prior to hunting these private lands. The remainder of the private lands on this unit either do not occur in Pronghorn habitat or are scattered and unmarked.

Deer: Deer concentrate on private lands at the mouths of Cottonwood, Hay, and Bitter Creek Canyons. Please secure written permission prior to hunting these private lands. They are relatively small parcels so they are easy to avoid but they do concentrate deer.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand County--Boundary begins at the Utah-Colorado state line and the summit and drainage divide of the Book Cliffs; west along this summit and drainage divide to Diamond Ridge; southwest along Diamond Ridge and the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide) to the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation boundary (Hells Hole/head of Sego Canyon); west along this boundary to the Green River; south along this river to Swasey’s Boat Ramp and the Hastings Road; south on this road to SR-19; south and east on SR-19 to Exit 164 on 1-70 near the town of Green River; east along I-70 to the Utah-Colorado state line; north along this state line to the summit and drainage divide of the Book Cliffs. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THE BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Moab, Westwater. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Some private land exists on the unit make sure to check map for specific details.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There is a campground up the main Oak Creek canyon.  Wilderness camping is also available on the unit.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are two main access points on the mountain.  Up Oak Creek canyon and Fool Creek Peak road.

huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Juab and Millard counties--Boundary begins at SR-50 and I-15 near Holden; north on I-15 to the Mills road; west on this road to the railroad tracks; west on these tracks to the Sevier River; north along this river to SR-132; west on SR-132 to SR-125 (300 East in Leamington); south on SR-125 to McCormick Road (CR-4549); south on this road to Whiskey Creek Road; southeast on this road to SR-50 in Holden; north on SR-50 to I-15.  Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Delta, Lynndyl. Boundary Questions? Call Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM. The National Park Service manages Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and Horse Shoe National Park. These areas are interspersed with SITLA land. There is is also private land on Mt. Ellen, Mt. Hillers, and leased land on Mt. Holmes.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: There are no DWR Wildlife Management Areas
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There are three managed campgrounds on the Henry Mtns. Two on Mt Ellen: Lonesome Beaver and McMillan, and Mt. Hillers: Star Springs. Direct questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Hanksville BLM Field Office. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield/recreation_/henry_mountains.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
Deer, Bison, Elk: There are several Henry Mountain access roads. Mount Ellen can be accessed on the North from the Sawmill Basin road, travel south on 100 East in Hanksville. Access to the east side of Mt Ellen is from the Little Egypt road at mile marker 20 off of SR95. Access to the west side of Ellen and Pennell is off the Notom/Burr Trail road, turn east at the Sandy Ranch. The east side of Mount Pennell and the north side of Mount Hillers can be accessed from the Coyote Benches/Stanton Pass road off of SR276. The east and south side of Mount Hillers can be accessed from the Star Springs road also off of SR276. All these roads connect with each other so there is general access to various areas across the mountain range.The BLM has put up good signage to get you around.

Desert Bighorn Sheep: Some of the best access is from Lake Powell on the east side of the unit. From the lake you can access Trachyte, Two Mile, Four Mile, Peshliki, and Ticaboo drainages. SR95 through North Wash follows along the North side of the unit and hwy 276 which travels along the west side of Mt. Holmes and Elsworth and the east side Mt. Hillers. From the map you will see a few stem roads going east off of SR276. One accesses Trachyte Point for about 3 miles where it ends above Hog Springs. Another road stems towards Mt. Holmes and Fred Ridge but this soon dead ends at a private property gate. Another road stems also to Mt. Ellsworth. Ticaboo Mesa is also accessed from SR276, this road runs along the southern side of Mt. Ellsworth and overlooks the canyon forks of Ticaboo Creek and other canyons and mesas to the North.

The following link on the BLM website provides a good map of the general boundaries of the five BLM Wilderness Study Areas (WSAs) located in the hunt unit surrounding the Henry Mountains, as well as the motorized travel designations which presently exist on public lands in this area. This map is available at: https://www.blm.gov/sites/blm.gov/files/uploads/BLMUtahHenryMountainsMap.pdf
USGS maps are available at the BLM in Hanksville: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Escalante, Hanksville, Hite Crossing, and Loa. They have a general map that labels most of the main roads. The BLM also has good road signage to help you navigate.

huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Deer and Bison: 4 wheel drive is highly recommended on the Henry Mountains. Roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, Wayne and Garfield counties, and SITLA, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. The Cave Flat road has a temporary closure November 1st – May 15th. Direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Hanksville BLM Field Office, SITLA, and the county you are traveling. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield/recreation_/henry_mountains.html

Desert Bighorn: The few stem roads east off of SR276 would be best with an ATV. Direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Hanksville BLM Field Office, SITLA, and the county you are traveling.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Capital Reef National Park (CRNP). CRNP strictly regulates all hunting activity and access through the Park which is limited to the Swap Canyon trail on foot or by horse. At the end of the Cow Bison Orientation is detailed information about bison hunting and CRNP. You can see the orientation here. Contact Capital Reef National park for more information. http://www.nps.gov/care/contacts.htm

There is private property on both Mount Ellen and Mount Hillers. Mount Holmes also has private leased property. Written permission from the landowner/lessee is required by law to access and hunt private land.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Garfield, Kane and Wayne counties--Boundary begins on SR-95 at a point two miles south of Hanksville; south on SR-95 to Lake Powell; south along the west shore of Lake Powell to SR-276 at Bullfrog; north on SR-276 to the Burr Trail-Notom road; north on this road to the Capitol Reef National Park boundary; north on this boundary to the Burr Trail-Notom road at The Narrows and Divide Canyon; north on this road to a point two miles south of SR-24; east along a line that is two miles south of SR-24 to SR-95. EXCLUDES ALL NATIONAL PARKS. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Escalante, Hanksville, Hite Crossing, Loa. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public and private.  Public lands are primarily Bureau of Land Management (BLM) managed out of the Moab Field Office.  This unit is situated adjacent to the Colorado border, Utah hunting permits are not valid in Colorado.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are no official camp sites on this unit. Camping is permitted on most of the BLM and SITLA lands. Please direct all questions regarding camping questions to SITLA or the BLM. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
SITLA: http://trustlands.utah.gov/business-groups/surface/recreational-use-of-trust-lands/
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/prog/recreation_home/activities/camping.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Access is very limited.  Safest route is through Glade Park CO.  There is also access to the Dolores Triangle by crossing the Dolores River, but this route can be impassible depending on river conditions (use caution).

Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the Utah State Institutional Trust Lands and the Bureau of Land Management and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to SITLA or the BLM.
SITLA: http://trustlands.utah.gov/business-groups/surface/recreational-use-of-trust-lands/

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are some private lands on this subunit, hunters must receive written permission before hunting private lands.  Be sure to pay attention to where you are, and study maps before your hunt, please respect ALL posted lands.  The Colorado border is on the Eastern side of this unit, Utah hunting permits are not valid in Colorado.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Manti-La Sal National Forest and The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) managed out of the Monticello Field Office.  This unit also includes Ute Tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members The Tribal lands are mostly in the South Cottonwood area of the unit in the lower canyons.

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are some private lands on this subunit, hunters must receive written permission before hunting private lands. Be sure to pay attention to where you are, and study maps before your hunt, please respect ALL posted lands.  San Juan, Elk Ridge deer permits are not valid on Native American lands.

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The boundary of this hunt unit does not include Tribal Trust Lands, but does have private land included.  There is private property on Diamond Mountain.  You should receive written permission from the landowner before hunting on private property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Daggett and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at the Utah-Colorado state line and the Green River at Browns Park; west along this river to Gorge Creek; south along Gorge Creek to the USFS/private land boundary at the head of Davenport Draw; south along the USFS/private land boundary on the west side of Davenport Draw to the BLM boundary; south along the BLM boundary approximately one-third of a mile to the rim of Diamond Mountain; south and easterly along this rim until the rim intersects the Diamond Mountain road (Jones Hole Road); south and west on this road to the Brush Creek road; south on this road to the Island Park/Rainbow Park road; east on this road to the Dinosaur National Monument boundary; north and east on this boundary to the Utah-Colorado state line; north on this state line to the Green River. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Dutch John. Boundary questions? Call Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM and Forest Service. There is private land as well and some of it is accessible through the DWR’s Walk-in-Access Program (https://wildlife.utah.gov/fishing/walk-in-access.html/).
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: There are no WMA's in this unit.

There are many dispersed camping sites within this unit. There are campgrounds located at Vernon Reservoir and Simpson Springs.

Salt Lake BLM Field Office - http://www.blm.gov/office/salt-lake-field-office

huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
Hunters may notice many areas where juniper trees have been cut down. These activities are to improve wildlife habitat for mule deer and sage-grouse and will have a long-term positive impact.
There are few private ranches that post their property. There are also privately owned lands that allow access or are enrolled through the DWR Walk-in-Access Program. Please be familiar with Utah trespass laws and always be considerate when accessing private lands. Private land is critical to this unit, please stay on the roads, close gates and do not harass livestock.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public lands are all Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley and Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forests.  This unit includes a large portion of the High Uintas Wilderness Area where all motor vehicles are prohibited.  This unit also includes large tracts of Ute tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members.  The tribal lands are mostly the lower elevation sagebrush zone but in some areas they reach up into the aspen/conifer zone.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit too.  Most of the private property is below the tribal boundary but there are several parcels of private property in the canyon bottoms.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Little Montes Creek WMA north of Ballard and Kevin Conway WMA southeast of Myton.  Elk, bear and cougar are rarely found on these WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:

There are special restrictions on camping and campfires in certain areas within the Wilderness area. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP:
The vast majority of the habitat from Argyle Canyon south is privately owned. Many of these properties are enrolled in the CWMU program where a separate hunting permit is required for big game on their property and they can not allow access. On this part of the unit there are only small isolated parcels of public lands on summer ranges to hunt. Prior permission must be secured before hunting on private lands. There is more public land on the northern third of the unit near Anthro Mountain. There is a mix of USFS and BLM lands in this area although wildlife densities tend to be lower in this area.

Anthro Subunit
Public, Private and Tribal Lands. The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley National Forest and The Bureau of Land Management(BLM) managed out of the Vernal Field Office. This unit also includes large tracks of Ute Tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members. The Tribal lands are mostly on the North end of the unit in the pinyon/juniper belt, with heavy oil field activity. The private land on the unit is primarily North of the Tribal boundary and in the low elevation desert areas and agricultural lands. There are two CWMU's on the unit (Antelope Creek and Cottonwood Ridge).

Range Creek Subunit
Most of the high elevation summer and early fall habitat is privately owned. Much of this private land occurs on 5 CWMU's (Preston Nutter Ranch, Patmos Ridge, Roan Cliffs, Conover-Jensen, and Minnie Maud CWMU's). Public lands occur at mid elevations and on the winter range. The vast majority of Nine Mile Canyon is privately owned.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT:
The Cold Springs WMA exists on good habitat near the town of Sunnyside

The Cottonwood WMA exists on the Anthro subunit.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are no known developed campgrounds on the unit. There are ample opportunities for dispersed camping on BLM and SITLA properties. No camping is allowed on the Cold Springs WMA. Please consult the Price BLM office for any camping restrictions at http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/price.html

Anthro Subunit
There are no official campgrounds on this unit. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites. Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The Nine Mile Canyon road is accessed from SR6 in Wellington.  It will provide access to Minnie Maud Canyon, lower Argyle Canyon, Harmon Canyon, as well as Cottonwood and Cedar Ridges.  The Bruin Point road is accessed via SR123 in the town of Sunnyside.  This road is impassible during the winter months.

huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Most major roads are maintained by Carbon, Emery, and Duchesne Counties. The Bruin Point dugway and Cottonwood Canyon dugway are both very steep and should not be attempted if there is a bunch of snow without tire chains. Pulling a camper trailer up the Bruin Point Dugway is possible but difficult. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Price BLM office at http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/price.html

The hunt unit does not include Ute Tribal lands as shown on the hunt boundary map on the Division's website.  There are several access roads across Tribal Lands in the Anthro Mountain area, for information on which roads are legal access roads contact Duchesne County.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal Lands.

This unit has a high percentage of private property on high elevation summer habitat, much of this property is managed as  CWMU’s. All private land requires written permission before hunting.  On this unit it is absolutely essential to have a map showing land ownership prior to hunting as most public land parcels are small and isolated and often surrounded by posted private property.  A GPS unit is also very handy.

huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION Central Federal Lands Highway Division (CFLHD), in partnership with Wasatch County, Utah County, and the United States Forest Service (USFS) is planning to improve Strawberry Sheep Creek Road, a 31.9 mile route between US-6 and US-40. This road is really 
ROAD CLOSURE CONSIDERATIONS The key objective is to construct these roadway improvements while minimizing impacts to public users. To facilitate public safety, certain segments of the road will be closed during various construction activities. When the road is open, delays up to 30 minutes can be expected. The construction schedule is subject to change. During road closures, no motorized vehicles will be permitted on the route. Adjacent Off Highway Vehicle (OHV) trail routes will continue to be open during road closures. Where a potential conflict between an OHV and construction equipment is possible, the OHV access will be restricted for public safety. Emergency access will be permitted at all times.
ROAD CLOSURE PRELIMINARY SCHEDULE
a combination of three smaller routes, Sheep Creek – Rays Valley Road (FR 70051); Unicorn Ridge – Indian Creek Road (FR 70042); and West Side Strawberry Road (FR 70131). The construction work will be split into four segments: Segment 1 (FR 70051) begins at the MP 0.0 (intersection with US-6) and ends at MP 7.0 (FR 70042). The work on Segment 1 consists of pavement rehabilitation including patching, crack sealing, and chip sealing. Segment 2 and Segment 3 (FR 70042) begins at MP 7.0 and ends at FR 70131. The work on Segment 2 and 3 consists of roadway bench widening, paving, drainage improvements, and safety improvements. Segment 4 (FR 70131) begins at the intersection with FR 70042 and ends 3.75 miles north of the intersection. The work on Segment 4 consists of pavement rehabilitation, pulverizing, and paving with subexcavation as needed.
QUESTIONS? Wasatch County Public Works 1891 West 3000 South Heber City, Utah 84032 435-654-1661 www.wasatch.utah.gov
Utah County

huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Elbow Ranch WMA - The Elbow Ranch WMA is a large winter range area. Do not expect high numbers of big game or bears to use this area during most hunting seasons.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There is only one official campground located on the unit. This campground is owned by the Koosharem Band of Piutes and is located adjacent to Koosharem reservoir. Hotel/camping accommodations exist in cities and towns that surround the unit. There is also a nearby campground at Otter Creek State Park. Camping outside of official campgrounds is permitted on most public ground. Please direct camping questions to the appropriate land management agency. Fishlake National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/fishlake
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are several main access roads to the Monroe unit. You can access the north side via road #068 from either the town of Annabella or Glenwood. This is a well maintained gravel road. From the east side you can take road #076 out of Koosharem and #069 out of Greenwich. Road #069 is the best road to take if you are pulling camp a trailer. The south end of the mountain can be accessed with the Pole canyon road (#072) near Angle or the Monroe Mountain road (#068) near Kingston. Both of these are maintained but are rather narrow and not recommended for large trailers. To access the west side of the unit use the Dry Creek road (#071) or the Monroe Canyon road (#078). Both of these roads are not recommended for trailers.

huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV and Vehicle Access: The Monroe unit has an extensive road and trail system. Many good areas to hunt can be accessed via vehicle. During the early hunting seasons most all roads and trails can be accessed. During later seasons early and heavy snows may make travel difficult. Some trails are restricted to ATVs of a certain size only. Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/fishlake/maps-pubs

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Forest Service, BLM, State, Private
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Kingston Canyon WMA is on the north end and has sportsman access, but it is all on foot.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: No campgrounds are located on the unit but dispersed camping is available.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: You can access the south end of the unit from the Tom Best Spring road off of HWY 12. You can access the east side of the unit on several different access point along SR-22 (John's Valley Highway). The north end of the unit is inaccessible except by foot. The west side of the unit can be accessed by several points from Circleville to Panguitch along HWY 89. I would access the top of the mountain using the Jones Corral or Cottonwood loop road.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USFS, and BLM land maps.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV's are a good way to access the units. Several roads are impassible by vehicle so an ATV would be recommended.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Garfield and Piute counties—Boundary begins at US-89 and SR-62; south on US-89 to SR-12; east on SR-12 to the Widtsoe-Antimony Road; north on this road to SR-22; north on SR-22 to SR-62; west on SR-62 to US-89. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Escalante, Loa, Panguitch. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: BLM, USFS, SITLA with some private parcels scattered throughout the unit.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Please refer all campground questions to the appropriate land management agency. Fish Lake and Dixie National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: SR-72 near Loa and Torrey
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Loa, Salina.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
There is an expansive road and trail system on this unit. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and USFS. Most Travel regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated to the Fish Lake and Dixie National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield and Escalante. The USFS has a travel map that covers most of this area. 
http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/fishlake/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Sevier and Wayne counties—Boundary begins at the junction of SR-24 and SR-72; east on SR-24 to the Caineville Wash road; north along the Caineville Wash road to the Cathedral Valley road; west on the Cathedral Valley road to Rock Springs Bench and the Last Chance Desert road; north on the Last Chance Desert road to the Blue Flats road; north and east on the Blue Flats road to the Willow Springs road; north on the Willow Springs road towards Windy Peak and the Windy Peak road; west on the Windy Peak road to SR-72; south on SR-72 to SR-24. Private lands within this boundary are open to general deer hunting. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Salina, San Rafael Desert, Loa, Hanksville. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of the land within the unit is owned by the USFS and the BLM and is open to the public. There are some large tracts of private land, many of which are enrolled in the CWMU program and you must possess a valid CWMU permit to hunt big game there. Permission by landowner may be granted by to hunt cougars on the CWMUs
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: n/a
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are many improved Camping areas on the Fish Lake unit, both public and private. Good camping exists in Gooseberry area, Elk Horn, multiple areas around Fish Lake and Johnson Reservoir. Primitive camping is allowed on much of the BLM and USFS managed lands. There is one improved campground managed by the Piute tribe near Koosharem reservoir. Contact the managing agency for detailed information. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/richfield.html
http://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/fishlake/recreation/camping-cabins
http://www.recreation.gov/unifSearchResults.do
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are many ways to access this unit. The north end can be accessed off of I-70 at the Gooseberry exit and also at the Hwy 72 exit. There are also many smaller unimproved roads that get you into good country from the frontage road along I-70. Access to the eastern side of the unit is via hwy 72. Roads that fork from hwy 72 that get you into good county include the Last Chance road, Road #206 that gets you onto the Thousand Lake Mountain, road #036 that takes you past Mill Meadow Reservoir and to Fish Lake.  There are many ATV trails and smaller unimproved roads that fork off of Hwy 72. The main access on the south end is SR-25 to Fish Lake via SR-24.   The west side is accessed via several dirt roads including the Hancock Flat road off of SR-25,  Road #053 that forks off of SR-24 gets you into the Rex Reservoir, and the Lost Creek country.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps Loa, Salina.  USFS Travel Management Map
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: There is an expansive road and trail system on this unit. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, USFS, Sevier and Wayne counties. Most travel regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated to the Fish Lake National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield and Loa. The USFS has a travel map that covers most of this area.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Private/Tribal Lands issues: There are several large tracts of private property on this unit. Several of these tracts are enrolled in the CWMU program and require special permits to hunt on them. Consult a good map to ensure you know where you are and to avoid any trespass conflicts
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Piute, Sevier and Wayne counties—Boundary begins at SR-24 and SR-72; west and north on SR-24 to I-70; east on I-70 to SR-72; south on SR-72 to SR-24. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps:  Loa, Salina. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: USFS, BLM, Private, SITLA
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: None
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Kanab and St George BLM Field Offices.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM: Kanab, St George, Cedar City
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and SITLA and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Kanab and St George BLM Field Office.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: This unit is largely private land.  Make sure you have written permission before entering private land.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Iron, Kane and Washington counties—Boundary begins at the Utah-Arizona state line and I-15; north on I-15 to SR-14; east on SR-14 to US-89; south on US-89 to US-89A; south on US-89A to the Utah-Arizona state line; west on this state line to I-15. This hunt is comprised of all or largely private property. Excludes Zion National Park. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Cedar City, Kanab, Panguitch, Saint George. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Land Ownership: Public, Private, State Trust Lands (SITLA). The public lands are Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and Dixie National Forest managed out of the Cedar City and St. George Field Offices, respectively. Ninety percent of the deer habitat is on public lands. There is one CWMU on the unit. The New Harmony CWMU is for deer and turkey. Information on maps can be found at: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/res/utah_public_room/maps.print.html http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/dixie/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: N/A
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are BLM and USFS campgrounds on the unit. Baker Dam campground for BLM lands is near Veyo. Some campgrounds on USFS land are Oak Grove, Honeycomb Rocks, and Pine Valley reservoir. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the BLM and the USFS. Cedar City and St. George BLM website: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/cedar_city/recreation.html
St. George Forest Service website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/dixie/recreation/ohv
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Information on maps can be found at: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/res/utah_public_room/maps.print.html http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/dixie/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: Stay on existing roads and trails. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and the Dixie National Forest and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to BLM and USFS. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/moab/recreation/motorized_routes/ohv_designations.html http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/st__george/recreation/motorized_recreation.html http://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/dixie/recreation/ohv
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The Shivwit Piute Tribe owns a large property west of Ivins.  This is primarily on deer winter range and would only be a factor during the any weapon deer hunt.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Iron and Washington counties—Boundary begins at the Utah-Arizona state line and I-15; north on I-15 to SR-56; west on SR-56 to the Lund highway; northwest on this highway to Lund and the Union Pacific railroad tracks; southwest along these tracks to the Utah-Nevada state line; south on this state line to the Utah-Arizona state line; east on this state line to I-15. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Caliente, Cedar City, Clover Mountains, Saint George. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM.  There is a significant amount of SITLA land.  There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA).  These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas. Private lands make up less than 5% of the total area and most are posted "no trespassing".
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, Willow Creek, and Little Creek WMAs
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html)
BLM:  14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days.
DWR WMA’S:  There is a 14 day limit on WMA’s, and there is no camping on the Willow Creek WMA.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
There are several access points to the Book Cliffs.  From the north side there are two main roads that take you to the Book Cliffs.  Utah State Road 88 located between Vernal and Roosevelt.  As you follow it south it turns into the Seep Ridge Road.  Hwy 45 or the Bonanza Hwy is located east of Vernal.  It takes you towards the east side of the Book Cliffs.  After you cross the White River you come to the Dragon or Duck Rock intersection.  The Dragon Rd will take you south to the Book Cliffs.

The Hay Canyon Rd is the main access road on the south side of the Book Cliffs.  You can access it from I-70.  It is a hard packed dirt/gravel road.  

The roadless area has two access points, a north and a south.  The north access is called the Ten Mile Knoll trailhead.  It is located at the start of Steer Ridge.  There is a parking area, but it can fill up in a hurry with trucks and horse trailers.  The south trail head starts at the top of Sego Canyon.  The road starts at Thompson Springs in Grand County and continues up the Sego Canyon Rd; follow it to the end of the road.  There is a water trough at the trailhead, but it is not always full of water.  This trailhead can also fill up with vehicles, and trailers.  There are no bathrooms or other facilities at either of these trailheads, so plan accordingly.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Primary Access Points:  There are several access points to the Book Cliffs.  From the north side there are two main roads that take you to the Book Cliffs.  Utah State Road 88 located between Vernal and Roosevelt.  As you follow it south it turns into the Seep Ridge Road.  Hwy 45 or the Bonanza Hwy is located east of Vernal.  It takes you towards the east side of the Book Cliffs.  After you cross the White River you come to the Dragon or Duck Rock intersection.  The Dragon Rd will take you south to the Book Cliffs.

The Hay Canyon Rd is the main access road on the south side of the Book Cliffs.  You can access it from I-70.  It is a hard packed dirt/gravel road.  

The roadless area has two access points, a north and a south.  The north access is called the Ten Mile Knoll trailhead.  It is located at the start of Steer Ridge.  There is a parking area, but it can fill up in a hurry with trucks and horse trailers.  The south trailhead starts at the top of Sego Canyon.  The road starts at Thompson Springs in Grand County and continues up the Sego Canyon Rd; follow it to the end of the road.  There is a water trough at the trailhead, but it is not always full of water.  This trailhead can also fill up with vehicles, and trailers.  There are no bathrooms or other facilities at either of these trailheads, so plan accordingly.    

ATV and Vehicle Access: 
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office, and SITLA.  The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.   

This unit includes the Book Cliffs Little Creek WMA (Roadless Area).  There is no vehicle access in this area and you are limited to horse or foot travel.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands.  There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit.  Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.  

There are some private ranches that post their property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at the Utah-Colorado state line and the White River; south along this state line to the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide); west along this summit and drainage divide to Diamond Ridge; southwest along Diamond Ridge and the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide) to the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation boundary (Hells Hole/head of Sego Canyon); west along this boundary to the Green River; north along the Green River to the White River; east along this river to the Utah-Colorado state line. EXCLUDING ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Vernal, Price, Westwater, Seep Ridge. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal Office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: There is some private land on the north end in Robins valley.  The larger tracts of private land are found on the south end of the Pahvant and along winter range.  See map for details.  There is plenty of public land with large numbers of deer available to hunt.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: WMA's are low elevation.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Established campgrounds are lower in elevation and can be found on the east side (Maple Grove) and on the west side (Maple Hollow - east of Holden; Meadow Creek - east of Meadow; Adelaide - East of Kanosh.  Many of these campgrounds are popular on weekends throughout the summer.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
East Side: Willow Creek (south of Scipio off of Hwy 50), Mountain roads (out of Joseph and Elsinore)

West Side: Kanosh Canyon Road out of Kanosh and Canyon Road out of Fillmore (Chalk Creek)
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Fishlake National Forest: Beaver and Fillmore Ranger Districts
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: See Map.  ATV's can be driven along the main roads as well as several ATV trails, with most of those trails being found toward the southern half of the Pahvant.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There is some private land on the north end in Robins valley.  The larger tracts of private land are found on the south end of the Pahvant and along winter range.  There is some tribal land found down low near Kanosh.  See map for details.  There is plenty of public land with large numbers of deer available to hunt.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Juab, Millard and Sevier counties--Boundary begins at SR-132 and SR-125 (300 E in Leamington); west on SR-132 to US-6; south on US-6 to SR-257; south on SR-257 to the Black Rock road; east on this road to I-15; south on I-15 to I-70; east and north on I-70 to US-89; north on US-89 to US-50 in Salina; north on US-50 to I-15 near Scipio; south on I-15 to Exit 178 and US-50; south on US-50 to Whiskey Creek Road; north on this road to McCormick Road (CR-4549); north on this road to SR-125; north on SR-125 to SR-132 in Leamington. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Delta, Lynndyl, Nephi, Richfield, Salina. Boundary Questions? Call Cedar City office, 435-865-6100
